attributes.category: Health Care Professional or Association - HC001
attributes.comment:
Re: CMS-0058-NC

Dear Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS),

Whenever I am a medical patient, one piece of information critical to my selection of and consent to treatment by any healthcare provider is the sex of the provider. My sex is crucial to the healthcare I seek and receive.

However, providers and patients are currently identified in the CMS Directory proposal only by the term “Administrative Gender” which is defined as, “The gender of a person used for administrative [recordkeeping] purposes.” This does not indicate the provider’s actual sex.

The documentation for this CMS Directory proposal states that “there are many considerations around sex and gender documentation” and that “various social and biological attributes” are relevant, so that, “in addition to this administrative gender, other kinds of gender or sex properties may be represented.”
Five other ways to represent a patient’s gender and sex are described.
1. Clinical Sex – a testable observation about a biological property. There are several different
types of clinical sex, including karyotypic/genetic/chromosomal, gonadal, ductal, phenotypic, etc
2. Clinical Gender – an observation about the patient.
3. Gender Identity – an indication from the patient about what gender he or she claims to be.
4. Sex assigned at Birth – the sex assigned at birth, as documented on the birth registration.
5. Legal Sex – The legal sex of a patient can vary from region to region and country to country. Which means a single patient may have multiple legal sex values at the same time in different jurisdictions.
It appears these will also be used to describe the gender and/or sex of healthcare providers in the proposed Provider Directory.

I am female, mother of two sons, grandmother of two small boys. The actual sex of my healthcare providers has always been critically important to me as a patient, especially with respect to the gynecological, obstetric and other medical care I have required over the course of my long female life. Other women share my concerns. But none of the proposed CMS classification definitions of gender/sex guarantee we will see a provider of the sex we choose.

In the proposed classification of “Clinical Sex” a man who appears female after taking female hormones and cosmetic surgeries might be listed as a female provider to any patient seeking only women providers. The classification “Sex assigned at Birth” may be changed or falsified later in life on birth certificates. The proposed category of “Legal Sex” would create a process by which any person could attain legal status of the opposite biological sex.

Any classification of healthcare providers must make it clear to patients what the objectively verifiable, biological (genetic/chromosomal/gonadic/reproductive) sex is of every provider. This is what I, and virtually every human being on earth, understands to be sex (as opposed to “gender”, which is based on cultural sex-based stereotypes. Men are not and cannot actually change their biological sex to female.

Denied this information, our relationship with our healthcare providers begins with deception rather than trust and care, and opens a path to charges of assault if a patient is assigned a provider of the sex the patient would not have chosen had the relevant information been made available.

The “gender identity” of medical professionals is irrelevant to me. My sex is what I expect to be relevant to them when I receive treatment. They are treating my female body, not cultural sex-stereotypes.
I need to know the sex of the healthcare provider involved in my care, especially in my intimate care (gynecological or otherwise); my consent to care is dependent on that information.
Which means, at a minimum, that the proposed Directory has a duty to provide clear information about the biological sex of patients and providers, unobscured by gender identity ideology. Ideally, the unverifiable and medically irrelevant notion of “gender identity” should be completely removed from the Directory.

I am a signatory to the Declaration on Women’s Sex-Based Rights, Article 1 of which states that organizations should “understand that the inclusion of men who claim to have a female ‘gender identity’ into the category of women in law, policies, and practice constitutes discrimination against women by impairing the recognition of women’s sex-based human rights.”

I write to urge CMS to reject the proposed changes to the Directory.
Patients have the right to clear and accurate knowledge about the sex of their chosen providers.

Your truly,
Leslie Sudock
Philadelphia, PA
